title: Mobile Social Search is a new frontier in search and problem solving

author: Ramesh Jain, University of California, Irvine

segmentation: When I put this topic for my talk, I was started wondering what is mobile social search and.

I went to my favorite topic of trying to decide what this whole thing means and I started looking at what could mobile social search really mean apart from the fact that we will talk about search, they talk about mobile search.
They talk about mobile, social, media and social search and all this kind of thing, and I'd derived inspiration from this diagram.
We are an elephant is not a wall, a rope, snake, spear, three or offend, then what is it?
Elephant and elephant.
It's just an elephant.
So what is mobile social?
But is it a mobile search?
Is it social or is it search?
The fact is that it is none of these.
It is just mobile social search.
So.
What is it?

What I want to present to you and discuss with you my views is that these are very interesting time in search and one of the most important things that is happening right now is that search is becoming really a part of problem solving in real time.

The thing that is most important is that with the mobile phones and with all the Internet of Things and all these kind of things happening, problem solving in real time is very easily possible for many many applications and that's what mobile social search is going to be.
It's going to be part of such problem solving.
What is very interesting about this is that when you start thinking about mobile social search, it's a problem of riches.
At one time we were very data poor.
We had very little amount of data, and that time we used to call it huge volume of data.
So when you go to 1995 and web and beginning of search engines like Yahoo's at that particular time, Yahoo used to claim that they are dealing with large data.
Data was miniscule compared to the data that we are dealing with and.
This is a very important thing to recognize that thinking in data, poor manners.
And thinking in data rich manner are very different problems.
We will have.
We start thinking about this problem dramatically differently, so let's first revisit what is search.
What kind of thing is that?
We are trying to do, so we are given data and we have users.
Data could come in many, many different forms.
Is starting from text that we are very used to to images that we think are important to audio to GPS data to all this kind of data and what we need to do is to connect these users to data.
Important word is connect.
Disconnect could be in many many different forms, so this is what our goal is.
How do we connect?
All this data to users.
What has been happening is that the nature of data has been changing dramatically when search engines started, we were dealing with data that was only in text form.
Nowadays data is starts appearing in all kind of forms.
This is a major transformation that has taken place in data.
In fact, what used to be very big size of data now is soon going to be much less than 1% of the data on the web.
Users, they had also been sending at one time.
We used to perform most of our searches on desktop and that was the environment in which we worked.
We went to the laptop later on today.
Most of the surveys are being performed by people either on smartphones or they are going down to people that you could not imagine at one time.
We will in remote parts of the world because now more than 80% of living humans are using mobile phones.
And these things are so powerful now that everybody is starting to utilize them for solving problems that require powerful search mechanic.
So what has been happening to service?
Let's consider some very simple examples how it was.
Let us say 20 years ago almost or maybe 17 years ago more how it what it is currently and how it's likely to be.
At one time I would ask a question.
What is an Italian restaurant on the search engine or I will say list Italian restaurants in Brussels?
Because I was working on desktop nowadays, my questions will be slightly different.
I will say so many Italian restaurants because my phone is with me.
It is it will be giving this and if I want to be the social service oriented then I will start saying use help.
And distance from me to rank them.
And this kind of things can be done more or less today.
What will happen in future?
I will start asking the question where should I go to eat Italian food now?
At this moment my system should consider how is the weather outside which Italian restaurants are closed by what is their popularity level but also equally important will be how busy they are.
It should not send me to a place where the weight line is one hour and the place is very loud because I want to have a meeting with somebody.
So this is the nature of search that it's ending.
Is the other thing.
That are happening all.
Let's consider the case of swine flow.
Luckily we don't have currently swine flu, but some of the data that I will show you comes from that time.
So the type of queries that happened earlier where?
What are the symptoms of swine flow?
This is the query that I will be asking.

Let later on today I would be much more interested in finding out is there a major swine flu outbreak outbreak in my area considering all the data that is available soon in future in the next few years.
Something really interesting is likely to happen.
There will be.

You will be walking based on your symptoms based on some of the devices like this that people have started wearing now the system will be measuring my body temperature will be missing my other parameters and based on that it will be saying you are also in the swine flu area.
So the an ambulance may come next to me and say let me take you to the hospital.
Because you are going to get swine flu and this will be result of all the.
So what does this really require?
We all are familiar with social networks.
We all know that the goal in life of social networks is to connect people to other people.
That's the only thing that social networks do.
Let's imagine that we change the concept slightly and we.
Start building something that, in absence of any other word, we started calling social life networks.
What social life networks do is the following thing.

In Edison to having just connecting people, you start putting all kind of devices all kind of data sources that are shown on the left hand side, including some of the devices that are able to take actions.
So in addition to sensors including human sensors or what some people call social sensors, you start putting actuators also on the Internet.
Once you have this you can do something extremely important and that is.
You can start connecting people to resources.
You can find out who needs what kind of resources and you can start connecting them to those kind of resources.
How do you do that?
We all talk about cloud computing and we all talk about big data.
We put this in the environment.
We do aggregation and composition of all this data sources that are coming in.
Based on this, we do what I call situation detector an.
From this situation detection, we go through all these mechanisms.
What is good is that the right hand side of information alerts and queries are techniques that we already know.
We're always using.
The big difficulties are in aggregation and composition.
And in situation recognition, if we can solve these two problems, it will help.
Us go to the next stage and that will be the state of how do we connect people to resources.
So in this case the big thing becomes says, how do we recognize the different situations?
But we in computer, within in speech processing and in text recognition?
We started search by concerning his strings string matching walls that our object or our basic entity that we wanted to match was a string of text in vision.
In audio.

We are still trying to define exactly what those objects would be because of the variability, but the important thing is if we start looking at this problem of concept recognition from data, we find something very important.
We are either trying to recognize visual objects or things like that or objects.

We are trying to recognize scenes, events, trajectories or we can go to multiple data sources and then we are trying to start recognizing real world objects or environments, activities or finally situations.
If you do little bit of Google search on some of these things you find interesting things.
There had been a lot of activities, for example when you start seeing this in the object recognition.
In the location aware devices and event recognition and so on.
But situation recognition is becoming a new area where you.
You see a lot of activities.
So the question becomes, is what is the situation?
What does the situation really mean?
One of my PhD students, after analyzing different types of situations came up.

With a very simple definition, by no means this is the final definition, but this has been a very good workable definition that we have been using little bit for the last two three years to run several experiments.
He defined situation, edge and actionable abstraction of observed spatial temporal characteristics.
Each word is important.
We want it to be actionable abstracts, and so you have a lot of data sources you are taking those data sources abstracting them.
Into something called situation.
These situations are usually actionable and all these characteristics are varying or changing over space and time.
Once we do this.
We need to have mechanisms to allow different users to define their own situations so that they can recognize what those situations are, and then they can build applications on top of this.
One simple example.
Flow data detecting swine flow.
This was the very first experiment that we started running.
In fact, the first experiment was related to detecting popularity of iPhone, but that was not that interesting because it was using only Twitter data for swine flu.
We started using data from Twitter data from Google searches and the data from all the hospitals that how many cases people were getting.
So we started combining those data and started.
Aggregating that data over United States over one, let one long area continuously at intervals of about four hours there.
So that will give us a map and in this map you can very easily define high and low activity zones.
That's what it is showing here.
The.
What we found was that in order to do this, we then started running all kind of experiments.
He, starting from hurricane alerts, to one of the popular things that we like to do is related to allergies.
An astronaut because you can get information from many, many sources, starting from people complaining on Twitter.
We will searching on Google, also from atmospheric data from weather.com.
You can get this Poland.
Can give you data.
All these sources provide you data in different forms, but and their different generality.
But the data is coming from many different sources.
So the first problem that you start facing is how can we represent all these data sources into one common format?
So we came up with this particular approach that let's start considering the data at multiple levels of granularity.
The fundamental thing is we are interested in space and time, so we start representing all this data in a grid format.

We are all familiar with the temperature Maps or representation of information in terms of different types of images containing different attributes, so we started extending that particular notion overtime and we started considering that at each.
At pixel type element, here you are combining information that could be coming from Twitter.
You are analyzing Twitter data.
You could be getting the data from NASA sources.
You could be getting data from any other source and if you are interested later on I will show you I can show you lots of different examples where we have tried to combine this.
But once you look at this sequence you go through this data.
The first level you combine the data from different sources.

Then you apply all kind of operators so that you can start detecting what kind of events are taking place at different pixel locations, and then you convert them to situation classification as things.
So the ultimately in this particular case, what you get is at the bottom.
That situation map.
Now this is the global map.
Representing the situation there in order to implement these things correctly and easily, we started thinking that when data is coming from so many different sources, how do we really combine that?
And we started implementing something called Events OP.
This is an open the we are making it available open source you want.
Today you can use it from our side, but right now we are not opening it.
You have to request us.
I think in two months we'll make it available to all the people who want to use it.

This does something very into.
Sting here as you see at the bottom we had a data cloud.
Data could be coming from any source.
It could be as obvious as the Twitter too.
You can get the Kneser data or any other sources of data and the front end it provides you with.
Easy to use interface, so this is how the system starts looking.
What you do is on the left hand side you can start selecting.
